title: MLOps
text: This page contains an outline of the topics, content, and assignments for the semester. Note that this schedule will be updated as the semester progresses, with all changes documented here.

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Sources

User input data

text, images, videos, uploaded files, etc.

Internal databases (services and applications)

Inventory
Customer relationship
‚Ä¶

System-generated data

Logs (tell you how the system is doing)
System outputs (like model predictions)

Third-party data



Log everything you can (makes debugging easier)

What exactly?
How?
How long?
Privacy regulations?

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Sources

First-party data

Data that your company already collects about your users or customers S

Second-party data

Data collected by another company on their own customers that they make available to you, though you‚Äôll probably have to pay for it

Third-party data

Companies collect data on the public who aren‚Äôt their direct customers

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Formats

How do I store multimodal data, e.g., a sample that might contain both images and texts?
Where do I store my data so that it‚Äôs cheap and still fast to access?
How do I store complex models so that they can be loaded and run correctly on different hardware?

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Formats

Store (‚Äúpersist‚Äù) data
Data serialization

Converting data into a specific format

Format depends on how data will be used

Human readability
Access patterns
‚Ä¶

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:

Format
Binary/Text
Human-readable
Example use cases




JSON
Text
Yes

Yes
Everywhere

No

No

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Row-Major Versus Column-Major Format

CSV (comma-separated values) is row-major
Parquet is column-major



Row-major formats

better when you have to do a lot of writes

Column-major

better when you have to do a lot of column-based reads.

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
NumPy vs pandas

pandas: built around DataFrame

Column-major

NumPy:

Major order can be specified

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Text vs Binary Format

Text files

Plain text
Human-readable
Not very efficient
E.g. CSV

Binary format

Nontext (only 0s and 1s)
Very compact
Not human-readable
E.g. Parquet files

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Text vs Binary Format
Store the number 1000000

Text file

7 characters
Each character 1 byte
7 byte

Binary file (as int32)

32 bits or 4 bytes

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Text vs Binary Format

File with 17,654 rows and 10 columns

CSV: 14 MB
Parquet: 6 MB

Parquet format is up to 2x faster to unload and consumes up to 6x less storage in Amazon S3, compared to text formats.

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Relational Models


Normalization

Reduces data redundancy
Improves data integrity

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Relational Models

Data follows a predefined data model (schema)
Relational databases

PostgreSQL
MySQL

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Relational Models
Ranking of the most popular relational database management systems worldwide, as of January 2022:

Source: Statista

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Relational Model

Query language for relational databases
Structured query language (SQL)

Declarative language

SQL queries can become quite long and complex

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
NoSQL

Not only SQL
Nonrelational models

Document model
Graph model (focus on relationships)

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Document model

Usally based on JSON, XML or BSON (Binary JSON)
Each document has a unique key
No enforced schema
Better locality

All information can be stored in one document
Content of each document is the priority

Less efficient to execute joins across documents

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Graph model


Graph model

Nodes
Edges represent the relationships between the nodes

Graph database

Relationships between data items are the priority

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Structured vs Unstructured Data

Structured data

Follows a predefined data model (data schema)
Easier to analyze
Storage in data warehouse

Unstructured data

Text, numbers, dates, images, audi etc.
Predefined data schema not necessary
Storage in data lake

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Structured vs Unstructured Data
Structured data | Unstructured data |
Schema clearly defined | Data doesn‚Äôt have to follow a schema |
Easy to search and analyze | Fast arrival |
Can only handle data with a specific schema | Can handle data from any source |
Schema changes will cause a lot of troubles | No need to worry about schema changes (yet), as the worry is shifted to the
downstream applications that use this data | | Stored in data warehouses | Stored in data lakes |

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
OLTP

Online transaction processing (OLTP)

Online transactions
Row-major
Low latency and high availability important

ACID

Atomicity (all or nothing)
Consistency (follows certain rules)
Isolation (multiple transactions)
Durability

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
OLAP

Online analytical processing (OLAP)

Column-major

OLTP and OLAP: Storage and processing is coupled

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text: Data Storage Engines and Processing

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Storage Engines and Processing
Today, we have transactional databases that can handle analytical queries and analytical databases that can handle transactional queries

Decouple storage from processing

Data stored in same place
Processing layer on top

Google‚Äôs BigQuery, Snowflwake, Terradata

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Storage Engines and Processing

Online
Nearline
Offline

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
ETL: Extract, Transfom, and Load


Data warehouse

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
section: ELT: Extract, Load, and eventually Transform
text:
ELT: Extract, Load, and eventually Transform

Data lake
Can be inefficient

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
section: Data warehouse + Data Lake = Data lakehouse
text:
Data warehouse + Data Lake = Data lakehouse

Structured data + unstructured data
Databricks lakehouse
Snowflake

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Modes of Dataflow
Data passing through:

Databases
Services using requests (e.g., GET)

REST (representational state transfer) API
RPC (remote procedure call) API

Real-time transport

e.g., Apache Kafka and Amazon Kinesis

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Databases

Problem of accessing
Easy but slow

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Services

Request-driven
Service-oriented architecture
Microservice architecture

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Services

Example Lyft
Driver management service

Predicts how many drivers will be available in the next minute in a given area.

Ride management service

Predicts how many rides will be requested in the next minute in a given area.

Price optimization service

Predicts the optimal price for each ride.

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Services


Request-driven data passing is synchronous

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Real-Time Transport


Broker

Coordinates data passing among services
In-memory storage to broker data

Event-driven architecture

Event: Data broadcast to a real-time transport
Event bus: Real-time transport

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Real-Time Transport

pubsup (publish-subscribe)

Service publishs to topic in a real-time transport
Service can subscribe to topic and read events

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Data Passing Through Real-Time Transport

message queue
Responsible for getting a to the right consumers

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text: Data Passing Through Real-Time Transport

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Batch Processing Versus Stream Processing

Historical data vs streaming data
Batch processing vs stream processing
Batch (static) features vs streaming (dynamic) features

title: Data Engineering Fundamentals
text:
Batch Processing Versus Stream Processing

Spark, MapReduce
Apache Flink, KSQL, Spark Streaming

text:
Summary

Data sources (first, second and third party)
Data formats

Row-major vs column-major
Text vs binary
Structured vs unstructured

Data models

Relational
Document
Graph


Data storage engines - Data warehouse - Data lake - Graph database

text:
Summary

Data processing

Transactional vs analytical

Databases

Pretty Code
Code
import pandas as pd
import altair as alt

# sorted bar chart

    x=alt.X('homeownership', sort='-y'), 
    y=alt.Y('count(homeownership)')
)

text:
Code Animations

Over 20 syntax highlighting themes available
Default theme optimized for accessibility

    x=alt.X('homeownership', sort='-y'), 
    y=alt.Y('count(homeownership)')

title: Template
text:
Line Highlighting

Highlight specific lines for emphasis
Incrementally highlight additional lines

import pandas as pd
import altair as alt

DATA = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kirenz/datasets/master/loan50.csv"

df = pd.read_csv(DATA)

# sorted bar chart
alt.Chart(df).mark_bar().encode(
    x=alt.X('homeownership', sort='-y'), 
    y=alt.Y('count(homeownership)')
).properties( 
    title='This is a simple bar chart',
    width=300,
    height=150
)

Learn more: Line Highlighting

title: Overview of ML Systems
text: Machine Learning

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
When to use Machine Learning

The system has the capacity to learn
There are patterns to learn, and they are complex
Data is available, or it‚Äôs possible to collect data
It‚Äôs a predicitve problem
Unseen data shares patterns with the training data

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Machine Learning characteristics
Machine learning is an approach to (1) learn (2) complex patterns from (3) existing data and use these patterns to make (4) predictions on (5) unseen data.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Additional characteristics

It‚Äôs repetitive
The cost of wrong predictions is cheap
It‚Äôs at scale
The patterns are constantly changing
It‚Äôs not unethical
It‚Äôs cost effective (in the long run)

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Typical Machine Learning Use Cases

Recommender system
Machine translation
Computer vision
Chat bots

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
ML Use Cases: Booking.com

150 Successful Machine Learning Models: 6 Lessons Learned at Booking.com

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Enterprise Machine Learning Use Cases

Fraud detection
Price optimization
Customer acquisition
Churn prediction
Customer service support
Brand monitoring (sentiment analysis)

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
State of AI
State of AI in 2022 by McKinsey & Company

title: Overview of ML Systems
section: Differences between ML in Research and Production
text:
Differences between ML in Research and Production









Research
Production




Requirements
State-of-the-art model performance on benchmark datasets
Different stakeholders have different requirements


Computational priority
Fast training, high throughput
Fast inference, low latency


Data
Static
Constantly shifting


Fairness
Often not a focus
Must be considered


Interpretability
Often not a focus
Must be considered

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Different Stakeholders and requirements

Consider a mobile app that recommends restaurants to users.
The app makes money by charging restaurants a 10% service fee on each order.
This means that expensive orders give the app more money than cheap orders.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
ML engineers
Want a model that recommends restaurants that users will most likely order from, and they believe they can do so by using a more complex model with more data.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Sales team
Wants a model that recommends the more expensive restaurants since these restaurants bring in more service fees.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Product team
Notices that every increase in latency leads to a drop in orders through the service, so they want a model that can return the recommended restaurants in less than 100 milliseconds.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
ML platform team
As the traffic grows, this team has been woken up in the middle of the night because of problems with scaling their existing system, so they want to hold off on model updates to prioritize improving the ML platform.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Manager
Wants to maximize the margin, and one way to achieve this might be to let go of the ML team.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Different Model Objectives

Model A: Recommending the restaurants that users are most likely to click on
Model B: Recommending the restaurants that will bring in the most money for the app
Which model should be deployed to the users?
Must-have vs nice-to-have requirements

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Kaggle vs ML in Production

Incentivizing the creation of more accurate models at the expense of other qualities valued by practitioners such as compactness, fairness, and energy efficiency
Ensemble vs compact model
Netflix price

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Computational priorities

Research usually prioritizes fast training
Production usually prioritizes fast inference
Research prioritizes high throughput 1
Production prioritizes low latency 2

how many queries are processed within a specific period of timethe time it takes from receiving a query to returning the result

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Latency

It‚Äôs a common practice to use high percentiles to specify the performance require‚Äê ments for your system
For example, a product manager might specify that the 90th percentile or 99.9th percentile latency of a system must be below a certain number

title: Overview of ML Systems
section: Data in research versus data in production
text:
Data in research versus data in production


Source: Andrej Karpathy, ‚ÄúBuilding the Software 2.0 Stack,‚Äù Spark+AI Summit 2018, video, 17:54, https://oreil.ly/Z21Oz.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Fairness

Loan application might be rejected due to biases in the model
Resume might be ranked lower because the ranking system picks on the spelling of names
Mortgage might get a higher interest rate because it relies partially on biased credit scores
Predictive policing algorithms
Personality tests administered by potential employers

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Fairness
In 2019, ‚ÄúBerkeley researchers found that both face-to-face and online lenders rejected a total of 1.3 million creditworthy Black and Latino applicants between 2008 and 2015.‚Äù When the researchers ‚Äúused the income and credit scores of the rejected applications but deleted the race identifiers, the mortgage application was accepted 1
Khristopher J. Brooks, ‚ÄúDisparity in Home Lending Costs Minorities Millions, Researchers Find,‚Äù CBS News, November 15, 2019, https://oreil.ly/UiHUB.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Interpretability

Interpretability is a requirement for many ML use cases in the industry
It‚Äôs important to understand why a decision is made so that we can trust a model and detect potential biases.
It‚Äôs important for developers to be able to debug and improve a model.

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
ML Systems

ML systems are part code, part data, and part artifacts created from the two
Usually applications developed with the most/best data win
Instead of focusing on improving ML algorithms, most companies will focus on improving their data
We need versioning for code and data

title: Overview of ML Systems
text:
Summary

Use cases of ML
When ML solutions would be appropriate
ML in research vs ML in production
How ML systems differ from traditional software systems




MLOps | Jan Kirenz

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Business and ML Objectives

Goal of any project is to increase profits

Directly: Increasing sales and cutting costs
Indirectly: e.g., higher customer satisfaction and increasing traffic on a website

Tie the performance of an ML system to the overall business performance

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
E Commerce example

E commerce site that cares about purchase-through rate
You want to move your recommender system from batch prediction to online prediction


E commerce site that cares about purchase-through rate and you want to move your recommender system from batch prediction to online prediction. You might reason that online prediction will enable recommendations more relevant to users right now, which can lead to a higher purchase-through rate. You can even do an experiment to show that online prediction can improve your recommender system‚Äôs predictive accuracy by X% and, historically on your site, each percent increase in the recommender system‚Äôs predictive accuracy led to a certain increase in purchase-through rate.

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Netflix Recommender example

Business metric: subscription cancellation rate
Metric: Total streaming hours
Netflix measures the performance of their recommender system using take-rate: the number of quality plays divided by the number of recommendations a user sees
The higher the take-rate, the better the recommender system
A higher take-rate also results in higher total streaming hours and lower subscription cancellation rates

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
A/B Testing

Use experiments to learn how ML metrics influence business metrics
A/B testing to choose the model that leads to better business metrics
Regardless of whether this model has better ML metrics.

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
ML maturity stage


How long it takes for a company to bring a model to production is proportional to how long it has used ML. Source: Adapted from an image by Algorithmia


Returns on investment in ML depend a lot on the maturity stage of adoption. The longer you‚Äôve adopted ML, the more efficient your pipeline will run, the faster your development cycle will be, the less engineering time you‚Äôll need, and the lower your cloud bills will be, which all lead to higher returns. According to a 2020 survey by Algorithmia, among companies that are more sophisticated in their ML adoption (having had models in production for over five years), almost 75% can deploy a model in under 30 days. Among those just getting started with their ML pipeline, 60% take over 30 days to deploy a model

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Reliability

The system should continue to perform the correct function at the desired level of performance even in the face of adversity (hardware or software faults, and even human error)
ML systems can fail silently

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Scalability

Ways an ML system can grow:

Complexity (more complex models)
Traffic volume (served predictions per day)
ML model count (# of models)

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Scalability

Resource scaling

Up-scaling (expanding the resources to handle growth)
Down-scaling (reducing the resources when not needed)
Auto-scaling: automatically scaling up and down the number of machines depending on usage.

Amazon‚Äôs autoscaling feature failed on Prime Day (2018), causing their system to crash. An hour of downtime was estimated to cost Amazon between $72 million and $99 million.
Artifact management (model monitoring and retraining)

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Maintainability

Code should be documented
Code, data, and artifacts should be versioned.
Models should be sufficiently reproducible

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Adaptibility

Adapt to shifting data distributions and business requirements
Capacity for performance improvement
Allowing updates without service interruption

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Iterative process

Developing an ML system is an iterative (never-ending) process.
Once a system is put into production, it‚Äôll need to be continually monitored and updated.
Example: Building an ML model to predict whether an ad should be shown when users enter a search query

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Iterative process workflow example


Choose a metric to optimize (e.g.¬†impressions)


Collect data and obtain labels


Engineer features


Train models


Error analysis (e.g., wrong labels -> relabel data)


Train the model again


Error analysis (e.g., data imbalance -> collect more data)


Train the model again


Model performs poorly on newer data -> update it on more recent data


Train the model again


Deploy the model


Model seems to be performing well, but revenue is decreasing -> change your model to optimize for ad click-through rate instead.


Go to step 1.

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Iterative process


Oversimplified representation of what the iterative process for developing ML systems in production looks like from the perspective of a data scientist or an ML engineer.

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Step 1: Project scoping

Identify and involve stakeholders.
Define goals, objectives, and constraints.
Estimate and allocate resources
Organize teams

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Step 2: Data engineering

Access to raw data
Handling data from different sources and formats.
Curate training data
Sampling and generating labels

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Step 3: ML Model development

Feature engineering
Model training and selection
Model evaluation

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Step 4: Model deployment

Make model accessible to users

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Step 5: Monitoring and continual learning

Monitoring for performance decay
Maintained to be adaptive to changing environments and changing requirements

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Step 6: Business analysis

Evaluate model performance against business goals
Eliminate unproductive projects or scope out new projects.
This step is closely related to the first step

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text: Types of ML Tasks

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Classification versus regression

Classification models classify inputs into different categories
Regression models output a continuous value

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Classification versus regression


A regression model can be framed as a classification model and vice versa (if we transform the data)

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Binary versus multiclass classification

Binary

Only two possible classes

Multiclass classification

More than two classes

High cardinality

Number of classes is high

Hierarchical classifiaction

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Multiclass versus multilabel classification

Binary and multiclass classification

Example belongs to one class

Multilabel classification problem

Example can belong to multiple classes

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
section: Multiple ways to frame a problem
text:
Multiple ways to frame a problem


This is a bad approach because whenever a new app is added, you might have to retrain your model from scratch, or at least retrain all the components of your model whose number of parameters depends on N

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
section: Multiple ways to frame a problem
text:
Multiple ways to frame a problem


In this new framing, whenever there‚Äôs a new app you want to consider recommending to a user, you simply need to use new inputs with this new app‚Äôs feature instead of having to retrain your model or part of your model from scratch.

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Objective Functions
To learn, an ML model needs an objective (loss) function to guide the learning process

Regression

Means squared error (MSE)
Root mean squared error (RMSE)
Mean absolute error (MAE)

Classification

Logistic loss (log loss) for binary classification
Cross entropy for multiclass classification

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives

Example: Build a system to rank items on users‚Äô newsfeeds
Original goal: aximize users‚Äô engagement
You want to achieve this goal through the following three objectives:

Filter out spam


Filter out NSFW content


Rank posts by engagement: how likely users will click on it

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives

Ethical concerns

Extreme posts tend to get more engagements
Algorithm learned to prioritize extreme content

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives

New goal:

Maximize users‚Äô engagement
While minimizing the spread of extreme views and misinformation

New objectives:


Filter out spam


Filter out NSFW content


Filter out misinformation


Rank posts by quality


Rank posts by engagement: how likely users will click on it




Two objectives are in conflict with each other. If a post is engaging but it‚Äôs of questionable quality, should that post rank high or low?

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives

Rank posts by quality

Minimize ‚Äúquality loss‚Äù

Rank posts by engagement

Predict the number of clicks each post will get
Minimize ‚Äúengagement loss‚Äù

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives
Possible solution: Train one model
\[loss = \alpha (quality_{loss}) + \beta (engagement_{loss}) \]






Warning


This is not a good idea




A problem with this approach is that each time you tune Œ± and Œ≤‚Äîfor example, if the quality of your users‚Äô newsfeeds goes up but users‚Äô engagement goes down, you might want to decrease Œ± and increase Œ≤‚Äîyou‚Äôll have to retrain your model.

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives
Better solution: Train two different models
\[\alpha (quality_{score}) + \beta (engagement_{score}) \]

Quality model

Minimizes quality_loss and outputs the predicted quality of each post

Engagement Model

Minimizes engagement_loss and outputs the predicted number of clicks of each post

Combine the models‚Äô outputs and rank posts by their combined scores


Now you can tweak Œ± and Œ≤ without retraining your models!

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Decoupling objectives

Multiple objectives

Decouple them

Makes model development and maintenance easier.
Easier to tweak your system without retraining models
Easier for maintenance (e.g., different maintenance schedules)

title: Introduction to ML Systems Design
text:
Mind versus Data

Mind

Intelligent architectural designs

Data

Computation

Success of an ML system depends largely on:

the quality and quantity of data it was trained on

Start with business objectives

Translate into ML objectives

General requirements:

reliability, scalability, maintainability, and adaptability

Iterative process

MLOps | Jan Kirenz

title: Training Data
text:
Nonprobability Sampling

Convenience sampling

Samples selected based on their availability

Snowball sampling

Future samples are selected based on existing samples

Judgment sampling

Experts decide what samples to include

Quota sampling

Select samples based on quotas for certain slices of data

title: Training Data
text:
Nonprobability Sampling

Sample is not representative for population (selection bias)

title: Training Data
text:
Simple Random Sampling

All samples in the population have equal probability of being selected
Easy to implement
Rare categories of data might not appear in your selection

title: Training Data
text:
Stratified Sampling

Divide population into similar groups
Sample from each group separately


Each group is called a stratum
Sometimes it‚Äôs impossible to divide all samples into groups

title: Training Data
text:
Weighted Sampling

Each sample is given a weight, which determines the probability of it being selected

title: Training Data
text:
Reservoir Sampling

Useful for streaming data


Put the first k elements into the reservoir.
For each incoming nth element, generate a random number i such that 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ n.
If 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ k: replace the ith element in the reservoir with the nth element. Else, do nothing.

title: Training Data
text:
Importance Sampling

Sample from a distribution when we only have access to another distribution

title: Training Data
text:
Hand labels

Expensive and slow
Label multiplicity

Annotate all entities they can find:
Annotator |# entities| Annotation |
1 | 3 | [Darth Sidious], known simply as the Emperor, was a [Dark Lord of the Sith] who reigned over the galaxy as [Galactic Emperor of the First Galactic Empire]. |
|2 | 6 | [Darth Sidious], known simply as the [Emperor], was a [Dark Lord] of the [Sith] who reigned over the galaxy as [Galactic Emperor] of the [First Galactic Empire].| | 3 | 4 | [Darth Sidious], known simply as the [Emperor], was a [Dark Lord of the Sith] who reigned over the galaxy as [Galactic Emperor of the First Galactic Empire]. |
